trans-unit.source: Integrate a cloud service with Azure CDN
trans-unit.target: Integrate a cloud service with Azure CDN

trans-unit.source: A tutorial that teaches you how to deploy a cloud service that serves content from an integrated Azure CDN endpoint
trans-unit.target: A tutorial that teaches you how to deploy a cloud service that serves content from an integrated Azure CDN endpoint

trans-unit.source: A cloud service can be integrated with Azure CDN, serving any content from the cloud service's ~/CDN path.
trans-unit.target: A cloud service can be integrated with Azure CDN, serving any content from the cloud service's ~/CDN path.

trans-unit.source: This approach gives you the following advantages:
trans-unit.target: This approach gives you the following advantages:

trans-unit.source: Easily deploy and update images, scripts, and stylesheets in your cloud service's project directories
trans-unit.target: Easily deploy and update images, scripts, and stylesheets in your cloud service's project directories

trans-unit.source: Easily upgrade the NuGet packages in your cloud service, such as jQuery or Bootstrap versions
trans-unit.target: Easily upgrade the NuGet packages in your cloud service, such as jQuery or Bootstrap versions

trans-unit.source: Manage your Web application and your CDN-served content all from the same Visual Studio interface
trans-unit.target: Manage your Web application and your CDN-served content all from the same Visual Studio interface

trans-unit.source: Unified deployment workflow for your Web application and your CDN-served content
trans-unit.target: Unified deployment workflow for your Web application and your CDN-served content

trans-unit.source: Integrate ASP.NET bundling and minification with Azure CDN
trans-unit.target: Integrate ASP.NET bundling and minification with Azure CDN

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will learn how to:
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will learn how to:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Integrate an Azure CDN endpoint with your cloud service and serve static content in your Web pages from Azure CDN</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Integrate an Azure CDN endpoint with your cloud service and serve static content in your Web pages from Azure CDN</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Configure cache settings for static content in your cloud service</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure cache settings for static content in your cloud service</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Serve content from controller actions through Azure CDN</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Serve content from controller actions through Azure CDN</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Serve bundled and minified content through Azure CDN while preserving the script debugging experience in Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Serve bundled and minified content through Azure CDN while preserving the script debugging experience in Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Configure fallback your scripts and CSS when your Azure CDN is offline</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure fallback your scripts and CSS when your Azure CDN is offline</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: You will deploy a cloud service Web role using the default ASP.NET MVC template, add code to serve content from an integrated Azure CDN, such as an image, controller action results, and the default JavaScript and CSS files, and also write code to configure the fallback mechanism for bundles served in the event that the CDN is offline.
trans-unit.target: You will deploy a cloud service Web role using the default ASP.NET MVC template, add code to serve content from an integrated Azure CDN, such as an image, controller action results, and the default JavaScript and CSS files, and also write code to configure the fallback mechanism for bundles served in the event that the CDN is offline.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial has the following prerequisites:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial has the following prerequisites:

trans-unit.source: An active <linkText>Microsoft Azure account</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: An active <linkText>Microsoft Azure account</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 with <linkText>Azure SDK</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 with <linkText>Azure SDK</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: You need an Azure account to complete this tutorial:
trans-unit.target: You need an Azure account to complete this tutorial:

trans-unit.source: You can <linkText>open an Azure account for free</linkText><title></title> - You get credits you can use to try out paid Azure services, and even after they're used up you can keep the account and use free Azure services, such as Websites.
trans-unit.target: You can <linkText>open an Azure account for free</linkText><title></title> - You get credits you can use to try out paid Azure services, and even after they're used up you can keep the account and use free Azure services, such as Websites.

trans-unit.source: You can <linkText>activate MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title> - Your MSDN subscription gives you credits every month that you can use for paid Azure services.
trans-unit.target: You can <linkText>activate MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title> - Your MSDN subscription gives you credits every month that you can use for paid Azure services.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will deploy the default ASP.NET MVC application template in Visual Studio 2013 to a cloud service Web role, and then integrate it with a new CDN endpoint.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will deploy the default ASP.NET MVC application template in Visual Studio 2013 to a cloud service Web role, and then integrate it with a new CDN endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions below:
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions below:

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio 2013, create a new Azure cloud service from the menu bar by going to File > New > Project > Cloud > Azure Cloud Service.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio 2013, create a new Azure cloud service from the menu bar by going to File > New > Project > Cloud > Azure Cloud Service.

trans-unit.source: Give it a name and click OK.
trans-unit.target: Give it a name and click OK.

trans-unit.source: Select ASP.NET Web Role and click the > button.
trans-unit.target: Select ASP.NET Web Role and click the > button.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: Select MVC and click OK.
trans-unit.target: Select MVC and click OK.

trans-unit.source: Now, publish this Web role to an Azure cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Now, publish this Web role to an Azure cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the cloud service project and select Publish.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the cloud service project and select Publish.

trans-unit.source: If you have not yet signed into Microsoft Azure, click the Sign In button.
trans-unit.target: If you have not yet signed into Microsoft Azure, click the Sign In button.

trans-unit.source: In the sign-in page, sign in with the Microsoft account you used to activate your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: In the sign-in page, sign in with the Microsoft account you used to activate your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: Once you're signed in, click Next.
trans-unit.target: Once you're signed in, click Next.

trans-unit.source: Assuming that you haven't created a cloud service or storage account, Visual Studio will help you create both.
trans-unit.target: Assuming that you haven't created a cloud service or storage account, Visual Studio will help you create both.

trans-unit.source: In the Create Cloud Service and Account dialog, type the desired service name.
trans-unit.target: In the Create Cloud Service and Account dialog, type the desired service name.

trans-unit.source: Then, click Create.
trans-unit.target: Then, click Create.

trans-unit.source: In the publish settings page, verify the configuration and click Publish.
trans-unit.target: In the publish settings page, verify the configuration and click Publish.

trans-unit.source: The publishing process for cloud services takes a long time.
trans-unit.target: The publishing process for cloud services takes a long time.

trans-unit.source: The Enable Web Deploy for all roles option can make debugging your cloud service much quicker by providing fast (but temporary) updates to your Web roles.
trans-unit.target: The Enable Web Deploy for all roles option can make debugging your cloud service much quicker by providing fast (but temporary) updates to your Web roles.

trans-unit.source: For more information on this option, see <linkText>Publishing a Cloud Service using the Azure Tools</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on this option, see <linkText>Publishing a Cloud Service using the Azure Tools</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: When the Microsoft Azure Activity Log shows that publishing status is Completed, you will create a CDN endpoint that's integrated with this cloud service.
trans-unit.target: When the Microsoft Azure Activity Log shows that publishing status is Completed, you will create a CDN endpoint that's integrated with this cloud service.

trans-unit.source: To create a CDN endpoint, log into your <linkText>Azure management portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To create a CDN endpoint, log into your <linkText>Azure management portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click New > App Services > CDN > Quick Create.
trans-unit.target: Click New > App Services > CDN > Quick Create.

trans-unit.source: Select http://*<servicename>*.cloudapp.net/cdn/ and click Create.
trans-unit.target: Select http://*<servicename>*.cloudapp.net/cdn/ and click Create.

trans-unit.source: Once your CDN endpoint is created, the Azure portal will show you its URL and the origin domain that it's integrated with.
trans-unit.target: Once your CDN endpoint is created, the Azure portal will show you its URL and the origin domain that it's integrated with.

trans-unit.source: However, it can take awhile for the new CDN endpoint's configuration to be fully propagated to all the CDN node locations.
trans-unit.target: However, it can take awhile for the new CDN endpoint's configuration to be fully propagated to all the CDN node locations.

trans-unit.source: Note that the CDN endpoint is tied to the path cdn/ of your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Note that the CDN endpoint is tied to the path cdn/ of your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: You can either create a cdn folder in your WebRole1 project, or you can use URL rewrite to strip all incoming links of this path.
trans-unit.target: You can either create a cdn folder in your WebRole1 project, or you can use URL rewrite to strip all incoming links of this path.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will take the latter route.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will take the latter route.

trans-unit.source: Back in the Azure portal, in the CDN tab, click the name of the CDN endpoint you just created.
trans-unit.target: Back in the Azure portal, in the CDN tab, click the name of the CDN endpoint you just created.

trans-unit.source: Click Enable Query String to enable query strings in the CDN cache.
trans-unit.target: Click Enable Query String to enable query strings in the CDN cache.

trans-unit.source: Once you enable this, the same link accessed with different query strings will be cached as separate entries.
trans-unit.target: Once you enable this, the same link accessed with different query strings will be cached as separate entries.

trans-unit.source: While enabling the query string is not necessary for this tutorial section, you want to do this as early as possible for convenience since any change here is going to take time to propagate to all the CDN nodes, and you don't want any non-query-string-enabled content to clog up the CDN cache (updating CDN content will be discussed later).
trans-unit.target: While enabling the query string is not necessary for this tutorial section, you want to do this as early as possible for convenience since any change here is going to take time to propagate to all the CDN nodes, and you don't want any non-query-string-enabled content to clog up the CDN cache (updating CDN content will be discussed later).

trans-unit.source: Ping your CDN endpoint to make sure that it's propagated to the CDN nodes.
trans-unit.target: Ping your CDN endpoint to make sure that it's propagated to the CDN nodes.

trans-unit.source: You may need to wait up to an hour before it will respond to pings.
trans-unit.target: You may need to wait up to an hour before it will respond to pings.

trans-unit.source: Back in Visual Studio 2013, open Web.config in your WebRole1 project and add the following code into the tag:
trans-unit.target: Back in Visual Studio 2013, open Web.config in your WebRole1 project and add the following code into the tag:

trans-unit.source: Publish the cloud service again.
trans-unit.target: Publish the cloud service again.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the cloud service project and select Publish.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the cloud service project and select Publish.

trans-unit.source: When the publishing status is Completed, open a browser window and navigate to http://*<cdnName>*.vo.msecnd.net/Content/bootstrap.css.
trans-unit.target: When the publishing status is Completed, open a browser window and navigate to http://*<cdnName>*.vo.msecnd.net/Content/bootstrap.css.

trans-unit.source: In my setup, this URL is:
trans-unit.target: In my setup, this URL is:

trans-unit.source: Which corresponds to the following origin URL at the CDN endpoint:
trans-unit.target: Which corresponds to the following origin URL at the CDN endpoint:

trans-unit.source: After URL rewrite in my Web app, the actual file that gets cached to my CDN cache is:
trans-unit.target: After URL rewrite in my Web app, the actual file that gets cached to my CDN cache is:

trans-unit.source: When you navigate to http://*<cdnName>*.vo.msecnd.net/Content/bootstrap.css, you will be prompted to download the bootstrap.css that came from your published Web app.
trans-unit.target: When you navigate to http://*<cdnName>*.vo.msecnd.net/Content/bootstrap.css, you will be prompted to download the bootstrap.css that came from your published Web app.

trans-unit.source: You can similarly access any publicly accessible URL at http://*<serviceName>*.cloudapp.net/, straight from your CDN endpoint.
trans-unit.target: You can similarly access any publicly accessible URL at http://*<serviceName>*.cloudapp.net/, straight from your CDN endpoint.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: A .js file from the /Script path
trans-unit.target: A .js file from the /Script path

trans-unit.source: Any content file from the /Content path
trans-unit.target: Any content file from the /Content path

trans-unit.source: Any controller/action
trans-unit.target: Any controller/action

trans-unit.source: If the query string is enabled at your CDN endpoint, any URL with query strings
trans-unit.target: If the query string is enabled at your CDN endpoint, any URL with query strings

trans-unit.source: In fact, with the above configuration, you can host the entire cloud service from http://*<cdnName>*.vo.msecnd.net/.
trans-unit.target: In fact, with the above configuration, you can host the entire cloud service from http://*<cdnName>*.vo.msecnd.net/.

trans-unit.source: If I navigate to http://az632148.vo.msecnd.net/, I get the action result from Home/Index.
trans-unit.target: If I navigate to http://az632148.vo.msecnd.net/, I get the action result from Home/Index.

trans-unit.source: This does not mean, however, that it's always a good idea (or generally a good idea) to serve an entire cloud service through Azure CDN.
trans-unit.target: This does not mean, however, that it's always a good idea (or generally a good idea) to serve an entire cloud service through Azure CDN.

trans-unit.source: Some of the caveats are:
trans-unit.target: Some of the caveats are:

trans-unit.source: This approach requires your entire site to be public, because Azure CDN cannot serve any private content.
trans-unit.target: This approach requires your entire site to be public, because Azure CDN cannot serve any private content.

trans-unit.source: If the CDN endpoint goes offline for any reason, whether scheduled maintenance or user error, your entire cloud service goes offline unless the customers can be redirected to the origin URL http://*<serviceName>*.cloudapp.net/.
trans-unit.target: If the CDN endpoint goes offline for any reason, whether scheduled maintenance or user error, your entire cloud service goes offline unless the customers can be redirected to the origin URL http://*<serviceName>*.cloudapp.net/.

trans-unit.source: Even with the custom Cache-Control settings (see <linkText>Configure caching options for static files in your cloud service</linkText><title></title>), a CDN endpoint does not improve the performance of highly-dynamic content.
trans-unit.target: Even with the custom Cache-Control settings (see <linkText>Configure caching options for static files in your cloud service</linkText><title></title>), a CDN endpoint does not improve the performance of highly-dynamic content.

trans-unit.source: If you tried to load the home page from your CDN endpoint as shown above, notice that it took at least 5 seconds to load the default home page the first time, which is a fairly simple page.
trans-unit.target: If you tried to load the home page from your CDN endpoint as shown above, notice that it took at least 5 seconds to load the default home page the first time, which is a fairly simple page.

trans-unit.source: Imagine what would happen to the client experience if this page contains dynamic content that must update every minute.
trans-unit.target: Imagine what would happen to the client experience if this page contains dynamic content that must update every minute.

trans-unit.source: Serving dynamic content from a CDN endpoint requires short cache expiration, which translates to frequent cache misses at the CDN endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Serving dynamic content from a CDN endpoint requires short cache expiration, which translates to frequent cache misses at the CDN endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This hurts the performance of your cloud service and defeats the purpose of a CDN.
trans-unit.target: This hurts the performance of your cloud service and defeats the purpose of a CDN.

trans-unit.source: The alternative is to determine which content to serve from Azure CDN on a case-by-case basis in your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: The alternative is to determine which content to serve from Azure CDN on a case-by-case basis in your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: To that end, you have already seen how to access individual content files from the CDN endpoint.
trans-unit.target: To that end, you have already seen how to access individual content files from the CDN endpoint.

trans-unit.source: I will show you how to serve a specific controller action through the CDN endpoint in <linkText>Serve content from controller actions through Azure CDN</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: I will show you how to serve a specific controller action through the CDN endpoint in <linkText>Serve content from controller actions through Azure CDN</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can specify a more restrictive URL rewrite rule to limit the content accessible through your CDN endpoint.
trans-unit.target: You can specify a more restrictive URL rewrite rule to limit the content accessible through your CDN endpoint.

trans-unit.source: For example, to limit URL rewrite to the \Scripts folder, change the above rewrite rule as follows:
trans-unit.target: For example, to limit URL rewrite to the \Scripts folder, change the above rewrite rule as follows:

trans-unit.source: With Azure CDN integration in your cloud service, you can specify how you want static content to be cached in the CDN endpoint. To do this, open Web.config from your Web role project (e.g. WebRole1) and add a element to . The XML below configures the cache to expire in 3 days.
trans-unit.target: With Azure CDN integration in your cloud service, you can specify how you want static content to be cached in the CDN endpoint. To do this, open Web.config from your Web role project (e.g. WebRole1) and add a element to . The XML below configures the cache to expire in 3 days.

trans-unit.source: Once you do this, all static files in your cloud service will observe the same rule in your CDN cache.
trans-unit.target: Once you do this, all static files in your cloud service will observe the same rule in your CDN cache.

trans-unit.source: For more granular control of cache settings, add a Web.config file into a folder and add your settings there.
trans-unit.target: For more granular control of cache settings, add a Web.config file into a folder and add your settings there.

trans-unit.source: For example, add a Web.config file to the \Content folder and replace the content with the following XML:
trans-unit.target: For example, add a Web.config file to the \Content folder and replace the content with the following XML:

trans-unit.source: This setting causes all static files from the \Content folder to be cached for 15 days.
trans-unit.target: This setting causes all static files from the \Content folder to be cached for 15 days.

trans-unit.source: For more information on how to configure the element, see Client Cache <clientCache>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on how to configure the element, see Client Cache <clientCache>.

trans-unit.source: In <linkText>Serve content from controller actions through Azure CDN</linkText><title></title>, I will also show you how you can configure cache settings for controller action results in the CDN cache.
trans-unit.target: In <linkText>Serve content from controller actions through Azure CDN</linkText><title></title>, I will also show you how you can configure cache settings for controller action results in the CDN cache.

trans-unit.source: When you integrate a cloud service Web role with Azure CDN, it is relatively easy to serve content from controller actions through the Azure CDN.
trans-unit.target: When you integrate a cloud service Web role with Azure CDN, it is relatively easy to serve content from controller actions through the Azure CDN.

trans-unit.source: Other than serving your cloud service directly through Azure CDN (demonstrated above), <linkText>Maarten Balliauw</linkText><title></title> shows you how to do it with a fun MemeGenerator controller in <linkText>Reducing latency on the web with the Azure CDN</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Other than serving your cloud service directly through Azure CDN (demonstrated above), <linkText>Maarten Balliauw</linkText><title></title> shows you how to do it with a fun MemeGenerator controller in <linkText>Reducing latency on the web with the Azure CDN</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: I will simply reproduce it here.
trans-unit.target: I will simply reproduce it here.

trans-unit.source: Suppose in your cloud service you want to generate memes based on a young Chuck Norris image (photo by <linkText>Alan Light</linkText><title></title>) like this:
trans-unit.target: Suppose in your cloud service you want to generate memes based on a young Chuck Norris image (photo by <linkText>Alan Light</linkText><title></title>) like this:

trans-unit.source: You have a simple Index action that allows the customers to specify the superlatives in the image, then generates the meme once they post to the action.
trans-unit.target: You have a simple Index action that allows the customers to specify the superlatives in the image, then generates the meme once they post to the action.

trans-unit.source: Since it's Chuck Norris, you would expect this page to become wildly popular globally.
trans-unit.target: Since it's Chuck Norris, you would expect this page to become wildly popular globally.

trans-unit.source: This is a good example of serving semi-dynamic content with Azure CDN.
trans-unit.target: This is a good example of serving semi-dynamic content with Azure CDN.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps above to setup this controller action:
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps above to setup this controller action:

trans-unit.source: In the \Controllers folder, create a new .cs file called MemeGeneratorController.cs and replace the content with the following code.
trans-unit.target: In the \Controllers folder, create a new .cs file called MemeGeneratorController.cs and replace the content with the following code.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to replace the highlighted portion with your CDN name.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to replace the highlighted portion with your CDN name.

trans-unit.source: Right-click in the default Index() action and select Add View.
trans-unit.target: Right-click in the default Index() action and select Add View.

trans-unit.source: Accept the settings below and click Add.
trans-unit.target: Accept the settings below and click Add.

trans-unit.source: Open the new Views\MemeGenerator\Index.cshtml and replace the content with the following simple HTML for submitting the superlatives:
trans-unit.target: Open the new Views\MemeGenerator\Index.cshtml and replace the content with the following simple HTML for submitting the superlatives:

trans-unit.source: Publish the cloud service again and navigate to http://*<serviceName>*.cloudapp.net/MemeGenerator/Index in your browser.
trans-unit.target: Publish the cloud service again and navigate to http://*<serviceName>*.cloudapp.net/MemeGenerator/Index in your browser.

trans-unit.source: When you submit the form values to /MemeGenerator/Index, the Index_Post action method returns a link to the Show action method with the respective input identifier.
trans-unit.target: When you submit the form values to /MemeGenerator/Index, the Index_Post action method returns a link to the Show action method with the respective input identifier.

trans-unit.source: When you click the link, you reach the following code:
trans-unit.target: When you click the link, you reach the following code:

trans-unit.source: If your local debugger is attached, then you will get the regular debug experience with a local redirect.
trans-unit.target: If your local debugger is attached, then you will get the regular debug experience with a local redirect.

trans-unit.source: If it's running in the cloud service, then it will redirect to:
trans-unit.target: If it's running in the cloud service, then it will redirect to:

trans-unit.source: Which corresponds to the following origin URL at your CDN endpoint:
trans-unit.target: Which corresponds to the following origin URL at your CDN endpoint:

trans-unit.source: After URL rewrite rule previously applied, the actual file that gets cached to your CDN endpoint is:
trans-unit.target: After URL rewrite rule previously applied, the actual file that gets cached to your CDN endpoint is:

trans-unit.source: You can then use the OutputCacheAttribute attribute on the Generate method to specify how the action result should be cached, which Azure CDN will honor.
trans-unit.target: You can then use the OutputCacheAttribute attribute on the Generate method to specify how the action result should be cached, which Azure CDN will honor.

trans-unit.source: The code below specify a cache expiration of 1 hour (3,600 seconds).
trans-unit.target: The code below specify a cache expiration of 1 hour (3,600 seconds).

trans-unit.source: Likewise, you can serve up content from any controller action in your cloud service through your Azure CDN, with the desired caching option.
trans-unit.target: Likewise, you can serve up content from any controller action in your cloud service through your Azure CDN, with the desired caching option.

trans-unit.source: In the next section, I will show you how to serve the bundled and minified scripts and CSS through Azure CDN.
trans-unit.target: In the next section, I will show you how to serve the bundled and minified scripts and CSS through Azure CDN.

trans-unit.source: Scripts and CSS stylesheets change infrequently and are prime candidates for the Azure CDN cache.
trans-unit.target: Scripts and CSS stylesheets change infrequently and are prime candidates for the Azure CDN cache.

trans-unit.source: Serving the entire Web role through your Azure CDN is the easiest way to integrate bundling and minification with Azure CDN.
trans-unit.target: Serving the entire Web role through your Azure CDN is the easiest way to integrate bundling and minification with Azure CDN.

trans-unit.source: However, as you may not want to do this, I will show you how to do it while preserving the desired develper experience of ASP.NET bundling and minification, such as:
trans-unit.target: However, as you may not want to do this, I will show you how to do it while preserving the desired develper experience of ASP.NET bundling and minification, such as:

trans-unit.source: Great debug mode experience
trans-unit.target: Great debug mode experience

trans-unit.source: Streamlined deployment
trans-unit.target: Streamlined deployment

trans-unit.source: Immediate updates to clients for script/CSS version upgrades
trans-unit.target: Immediate updates to clients for script/CSS version upgrades

trans-unit.source: Fallback mechanism when your CDN endpoint fails
trans-unit.target: Fallback mechanism when your CDN endpoint fails

trans-unit.source: Minimize code modification
trans-unit.target: Minimize code modification

trans-unit.source: In the WebRole1 project that you created in Integrate an Azure CDN endpoint with your Azure website and serve static content in your Web pages from Azure CDN, open App_Start\BundleConfig.cs and take a look at the bundles.Add() method calls.
trans-unit.target: In the WebRole1 project that you created in Integrate an Azure CDN endpoint with your Azure website and serve static content in your Web pages from Azure CDN, open App_Start\BundleConfig.cs and take a look at the bundles.Add() method calls.

trans-unit.source: The first bundles.Add() statement adds a script bundle at the virtual directory ~/bundles/jquery.
trans-unit.target: The first bundles.Add() statement adds a script bundle at the virtual directory ~/bundles/jquery.

trans-unit.source: Then, open Views\Shared\_Layout.cshtml to see how the script bundle tag is rendered.
trans-unit.target: Then, open Views\Shared\_Layout.cshtml to see how the script bundle tag is rendered.

trans-unit.source: You should be able to find the following line of Razor code:
trans-unit.target: You should be able to find the following line of Razor code:

trans-unit.source: When this Razor code is run in the Azure Web role, it will render a
trans-unit.target: When this Razor code is run in the Azure Web role, it will render a

trans-unit.source: However, when it is run in Visual Studio by typing F5, it will render each script file in the bundle individually (in the case above, only one script file is in the bundle):
trans-unit.target: However, when it is run in Visual Studio by typing F5, it will render each script file in the bundle individually (in the case above, only one script file is in the bundle):

trans-unit.source: This enables you to debug the JavaScript code in your development environment while reducing concurrent client connections (bundling) and improving file download performance (minification) in production.
trans-unit.target: This enables you to debug the JavaScript code in your development environment while reducing concurrent client connections (bundling) and improving file download performance (minification) in production.

trans-unit.source: It's a great feature to preserve with Azure CDN integration.
trans-unit.target: It's a great feature to preserve with Azure CDN integration.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, since the rendered bundle already contains an automatically generated version string, you want to replicate that functionality so the whenever you update your jQuery version through NuGet, it can be updated at the client side as soon as possible.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, since the rendered bundle already contains an automatically generated version string, you want to replicate that functionality so the whenever you update your jQuery version through NuGet, it can be updated at the client side as soon as possible.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps below to integration ASP.NET bundling and minification with your CDN endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps below to integration ASP.NET bundling and minification with your CDN endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Back in App_Start\BundleConfig.cs, modify the bundles.Add() methods to use a different Bundle constructor, one that specifies a CDN address.
trans-unit.target: Back in App_Start\BundleConfig.cs, modify the bundles.Add() methods to use a different Bundle constructor, one that specifies a CDN address.

trans-unit.source: To do this, replace the RegisterBundles method definition with the following code:
trans-unit.target: To do this, replace the RegisterBundles method definition with the following code:

trans-unit.source: Be sure to replace with the name of your Azure CDN.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to replace with the name of your Azure CDN.

trans-unit.source: In plain words, you are setting bundles.UseCdn = true and added a carefully crafted CDN URL to each bundle.
trans-unit.target: In plain words, you are setting bundles.UseCdn = true and added a carefully crafted CDN URL to each bundle.

trans-unit.source: For example, the first constructor in the code:
trans-unit.target: For example, the first constructor in the code:

trans-unit.source: is the same as:
trans-unit.target: is the same as:

trans-unit.source: This constructor tells ASP.NET bundling and minification to render individual script files when debugged locally, but use the specified CDN address to access the script in question.
trans-unit.target: This constructor tells ASP.NET bundling and minification to render individual script files when debugged locally, but use the specified CDN address to access the script in question.

trans-unit.source: However, note two important characteristics with this carefully crafted CDN URL:
trans-unit.target: However, note two important characteristics with this carefully crafted CDN URL:

trans-unit.source: The origin for this CDN URL is http://.cloudapp.net/bundles/jquery?v=, which is actually the virtual directory of the script bundle in your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: The origin for this CDN URL is http://.cloudapp.net/bundles/jquery?v=, which is actually the virtual directory of the script bundle in your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Since you are using CDN constructor, the CDN script tag for the bundle no longer contains the automatically generated version string in the rendered URL.
trans-unit.target: Since you are using CDN constructor, the CDN script tag for the bundle no longer contains the automatically generated version string in the rendered URL.

trans-unit.source: You must manually generate a unique version string every time the script bundle is modified to force a cache miss at your Azure CDN.
trans-unit.target: You must manually generate a unique version string every time the script bundle is modified to force a cache miss at your Azure CDN.

trans-unit.source: At the same time, this unique version string must remain constant through the life of the deployment to maximize cache hits at your Azure CDN after the bundle is deployed.
trans-unit.target: At the same time, this unique version string must remain constant through the life of the deployment to maximize cache hits at your Azure CDN after the bundle is deployed.

trans-unit.source: The query string v= pulls from Properties\AssemblyInfo.cs in your Web role project. You can have a deployment workflow that includes incrementing the assembly version every time you publish to Azure. Or, you can just modify Properties\AssemblyInfo.cs in your project to automatically increment the version string every time you build, using the wildcard character '*'. For example:
trans-unit.target: The query string v= pulls from Properties\AssemblyInfo.cs in your Web role project. You can have a deployment workflow that includes incrementing the assembly version every time you publish to Azure. Or, you can just modify Properties\AssemblyInfo.cs in your project to automatically increment the version string every time you build, using the wildcard character '*'. For example:

trans-unit.source: Any other strategy to streamline generating a unique string for the life of a deployment will work here.
trans-unit.target: Any other strategy to streamline generating a unique string for the life of a deployment will work here.

trans-unit.source: Republish the cloud service and access the home page.
trans-unit.target: Republish the cloud service and access the home page.

trans-unit.source: View the HTML code for the page.
trans-unit.target: View the HTML code for the page.

trans-unit.source: You should be able to see the CDN URL rendered, with a unique version string every time you republish changes to your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: You should be able to see the CDN URL rendered, with a unique version string every time you republish changes to your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, debug the cloud service in Visual Studio by typing F5.,
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, debug the cloud service in Visual Studio by typing F5.,

trans-unit.source: View the HTML code for the page.
trans-unit.target: View the HTML code for the page.

trans-unit.source: You will still see each script file individually rendered so that you can have a consistent debug experience in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: You will still see each script file individually rendered so that you can have a consistent debug experience in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: When your Azure CDN endpoint fails for any reason, you want your Web page to be smart enough to access your origin Web server as the fallback option for loading JavaScript or Bootstrap.
trans-unit.target: When your Azure CDN endpoint fails for any reason, you want your Web page to be smart enough to access your origin Web server as the fallback option for loading JavaScript or Bootstrap.

trans-unit.source: It's serious enough to lose images on your website due to CDN unavailability, but much more severe to lose crucial page functionality provided by your scripts and stylesheets.
trans-unit.target: It's serious enough to lose images on your website due to CDN unavailability, but much more severe to lose crucial page functionality provided by your scripts and stylesheets.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>Bundle</linkText><title></title> class contains a property called <linkText>CdnFallbackExpression</linkText><title></title> that enables you to configure the fallback mechanism for CDN failure.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>Bundle</linkText><title></title> class contains a property called <linkText>CdnFallbackExpression</linkText><title></title> that enables you to configure the fallback mechanism for CDN failure.

trans-unit.source: To use this property, follow the steps below:
trans-unit.target: To use this property, follow the steps below:

trans-unit.source: In your Web role project, open App_Start\BundleConfig.cs, where you added a CDN URL in each Bundle constructor, and make the following highlighted changes to add fallback mechanism to the default bundles:
trans-unit.target: In your Web role project, open App_Start\BundleConfig.cs, where you added a CDN URL in each Bundle constructor, and make the following highlighted changes to add fallback mechanism to the default bundles:

trans-unit.source: When CdnFallbackExpression is not null, script is injected into the HTML to test whether the bundle is loaded successfully and, if not, access the bundle directly from the origin Web server.
trans-unit.target: When CdnFallbackExpression is not null, script is injected into the HTML to test whether the bundle is loaded successfully and, if not, access the bundle directly from the origin Web server.

trans-unit.source: This property needs to be set to a JavaScript expression that tests whether the respective CDN bundle is loaded properly.
trans-unit.target: This property needs to be set to a JavaScript expression that tests whether the respective CDN bundle is loaded properly.

trans-unit.source: The expression needed to test each bundle differs according to the content.
trans-unit.target: The expression needed to test each bundle differs according to the content.

trans-unit.target: For the default bundles above:

trans-unit.target: window.jquery is defined in jquery-{version}.js

trans-unit.source: $.validator is defined in jquery.validate.js
trans-unit.target: $.validator is defined in jquery.validate.js

trans-unit.source: window.Modernizr is defined in modernizer-{version}.js
trans-unit.target: window.Modernizr is defined in modernizer-{version}.js

trans-unit.source: $.fn.modal is defined in bootstrap.js
trans-unit.target: $.fn.modal is defined in bootstrap.js

trans-unit.source: There is, however, a good <linkText>Style Bundle Fallback</linkText><title></title> offered by <linkText>Ember Consulting Group</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To use the workaround for CSS, create a new .cs file in your Web role project's App_Start folder called StyleBundleExtensions.cs, and replace its content with the code from GitHub.
trans-unit.target: To use the workaround for CSS, create a new .cs file in your Web role project's App_Start folder called StyleBundleExtensions.cs, and replace its content with the code from GitHub.

trans-unit.source: In App_Start\StyleFundleExtensions.cs, rename the namespace to your Web role's name (e.g. WebRole1).
trans-unit.target: In App_Start\StyleFundleExtensions.cs, rename the namespace to your Web role's name (e.g. WebRole1).

trans-unit.target: Go back to App_Start\BundleConfig.cs and modify the last bundles.Add statement with the following highlighted code:

trans-unit.source: This new extension method uses the same idea to inject script in the HTML to check the DOM for the a matching class name, rule name, and rule value defined in the CSS bundle, and falls back to the origin Web server if it fails to find the match.
trans-unit.target: This new extension method uses the same idea to inject script in the HTML to check the DOM for the a matching class name, rule name, and rule value defined in the CSS bundle, and falls back to the origin Web server if it fails to find the match.
